name: Water (Liquid H₂O)
description: Liquid water at standard conditions. The most common form of water on Earth's surface. Essential for all known life forms.

specificHeatLiquid.description: Energy needed to raise 1 gram by 1°C. Water has one of the highest specific heats, making it excellent for thermal storage.

heatOfVaporization.description: Energy needed to convert 1 kg of liquid at boiling point to steam. This is why steam burns are so dangerous.

heatOfFusion.description: Energy needed to melt 1 kg of ice at 0°C to liquid water at 0°C.

density.description: Mass per unit volume at 4°C (when water is densest). 1 liter of water = 1 kilogram. Water is unusual: it's less dense when frozen (ice floats).

boilingPoint.description: Temperature at which water boils at sea level (101.325 kPa). Decreases ~1°C per 300m elevation.

freezingPoint.description: Temperature at which water freezes at standard pressure.

molecularMass.description: H₂O: 2 hydrogen atoms (1.008 each) + 1 oxygen atom (15.999) = 18.015 g/mol

thermalConductivity.description: How well water conducts heat. Relatively low compared to metals, but significant for aquatic heat transfer.

viscosity.description: Resistance to flow at 20°C. Water is relatively fluid compared to oils or honey.

surfaceTension.description: Force per unit length at liquid-air interface. High surface tension allows water striders to walk on water.

refractiveIndex.description: How much water bends light. This is why objects underwater appear to shift position.

coolingModel.description: Newton's Law of Cooling coefficient for liquid water in a typical metal pot at room temperature. Determines exponential cooling rate: dT/dt = -k(T - T_ambient). Typical cooling: 100°C → 20°C in ~30-40 minutes without insulation.

visualProperties.transparency: High - can see through several meters in pure water
visualProperties.appearance: Clear, colorless liquid. Blue tint visible in deep volumes due to water absorbing red wavelengths.

equilibriumWithIce.description: At 0°C, ice and liquid water coexist in equilibrium

equilibriumWithSteam.description: At 100°C (at standard pressure), liquid water and steam coexist in equilibrium

biologicalProperties.description: Pure water is isotonic with cells at dilute concentrations. Living organisms cannot survive in pure water for extended periods.

globalAverage.description: Average temperature of liquid water in Earth's oceans

freezingRate.freshwater: ~15 cm per month in polar regions
freezingRate.saltwater: Slower due to salt ions depressing freezing point

evaporationRate.arid: Up to 10 mm per day in deserts
evaporationRate.tropical: 5-8 mm per day in humid tropics
evaporationRate.polar: 0.1-1 mm per day in polar regions

metadata.educationalNotes: Liquid water is the reference state for H₂O. The other states (ice and steam) are often studied in comparison to liquid water's properties. Water's high specific heat and heat of vaporization make it an ideal substance for studying thermodynamics.
metadata.historicalNote: Water was long thought to be an element until the 18th century when scientists discovered it was composed of hydrogen and oxygen gases.
